article.title: Optimal $(t,r)$ Broadcasts On the Infinite Grid

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the diamond shape around tower T in Figure 1 represent?
choices: The set of vertices dominated by tower T.
The physical area covered by the signal from tower T.
The broadcast outline of tower T, connecting vertices receiving a signal of 1.
The area representing the density of the broadcast from tower T.

multiple_choice_question.text: How is a half-square on the half-square grid defined in this article?
choices: By dividing a regular grid square into two equal triangles.
By the diagonal lines passing through the grid, creating squares with area 1/2.
By connecting the midpoints of adjacent grid squares.
By rotating the original grid by 45 degrees.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of grouping the vertices receiving signal from a tower of strength 3 into squares in Figure 3?
choices: It represents the minimum area that needs to be covered by any (3,1) broadcast.
It demonstrates that the number of vertices receiving signal from a tower of strength t can be calculated using squares of sizes t x t and (t-1) x (t-1).
It highlights the importance of the half-square grid in analyzing broadcasts.
It visually explains why the standard pattern p(13,5) is an optimal (3,1) broadcast.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 5 demonstrate about the standard broadcast T1,1?
choices: It shows that T1,1 creates holes of depth 1 within the grid.
It proves that T1,1 has a broadcast density greater than 1.
It illustrates how T1,1 divides the grid into square regions with towers at their corners, ensuring every vertex receives signal of at least 1.
It highlights the importance of overlap half-squares in achieving full coverage.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the key difference between the two regular tilings shown in Figure 7?
choices: The signal strength (t) used in each tiling is different.
One tiling represents a (t,1) broadcast, while the other represents a (t,2) broadcast.
The tilings are offset from each other, demonstrating different possible arrangements of broadcast outlines to achieve full coverage.
One tiling represents an optimal broadcast, while the other represents a non-optimal broadcast.
